column1: Subang Jaya is a city in Petaling District
column2: Selangor
column3: Malaysia. It comprises the southern third district of Petaling. Consists of neighbourhoods from SS12 to SS19
column4: PJS7/PJS9/PJS11 of Bandar Sunway (which are also partially jurisdictional within Petaling Jaya under the MBPJ)
column7: the city is governed by Subang Jaya City Council (MPSJ)
column8: which also governs other areas of the Petaling district
column9: such as Puchong and Seri Kembangan. According to the Subang Jaya City Council (Malay: MPSJ)
column10: Subang Jaya has a population of 642

column2: Subang Jaya was developed by Sime UEP Properties Berhad
column3: the property development arm of the Malaysian conglomerate Sime Darby. The site was formerly a rubber plantation called Seafield Estate under the municipality of Majlis Perbandaran Petaling Jaya. Construction work for the development of Subang Jaya (consists the neighbourhood of SS 12 - SS 19) began on 21 February 1976 and was concluded in 1988. Upon completion of Subang Jaya in the same year
column4: Sime UEP began clearing land for the development of USJ. In 1999
column5: Sime UEP began the development of Putra Heights which is located on the southern end of Subang Jaya.In 1997
column6: Subang Jaya received the status of a municipality
column7: elevating the Petaling District Council to Subang Jaya Municipal Council. The municipal comprise the areas administered by the former Petaling District Council
column8: as well as some areas transferred from Petaling Jaya
column9: Puchong and Shah Alam. This means that the MPSJ municipal holds local government authority not only in the Subang Jaya city centre
column18: Subang Jaya's municipal area covers the parliamentary constituency of Puchong and Subang in its entirety
column19: as well as parts of Kota Raja which mainly cover Putra Heights. On the west side of Subang Jaya
column20: Batu Tiga covers areas like Subang Hi-Tech Industrial Park
column22: Taman Subang Mas and Tropicana Metropark. Subang Jaya city itself lies within the Subang constituency
column23: while Seri Kembangan and Puchong fall within the Puchong constituency. In Dec 2019
column24: it was officially announced that Subang Jaya's municipality will be upgraded to a city council after a long 5-year wait since MPSJ's application in 2014.

column2: the Dewan Rakyat parliamentary constituency of Subang (P104
column3: formerly as Kelana Jaya) is represented by Wong Chen of the Pakatan Harapan-People's Justice Party (PKR) while the Selangor State Assembly seat of Subang Jaya is represented by Michelle Ng Mei Sze from the Pakatan Harapan-Democratic Action Party (DAP).

column2: Empire Subang
column3: Sunway Pyramid
column4: and SS15 Courtyard are the main shopping attractions around the areas of the Subang Jaya city centre. In the adjacent township of Bandar Sunway
column6: an amusement water theme park which is a tourist landmark across the nation.

column1: The commercial district of SS15 serves as Subang Jaya's central entertainment and business area. Within the area
column2: there is also an abundance of international F&B outlets
column3: cafes
column5: boutique outlets and banks.  There are plenty of high-rise office buildings and serviced residences surrounding the area as well. As of November 2017
column6: the Asia Cafe in SS15 is officially closed down to make way for the development of high-rise commercial building.

column2: there are shopping malls such as Da Men
column3: Main Place
column7: Giant USJ and Mydin USJ to provide more shopping options. The main commercial hub of the USJ township is USJ Taipan which is a bustling business area. There are many small-scale commercial areas scattering around the neighbourhoods of USJ to provide amenities and conveniences as well.

column1: The most renowned and largest recreation park in Subang Jaya is the Subang Ria Park
column2: situated nearby the Sime Darby Medical Centre in SS12. During its heyday in the 1990s
column3: the park was a boating place with tennis court
column4: paintball and go-karting arenas. As of 2015
column5: it was a park mainly used for jogging activities
column6: with a deterioration in the condition of other resources in the park after a number of years of neglect. For an urban park experience
column7: there is Tropicana Metropark which contains a 9.2-acre central park with features like a man-made lake with a bio-filtration system to prevent mosquito breeding
column8: a pedestrian promenade and a food-and-beverage strip for alfresco indulgence.The MPSJ Stadium in USJ 5 comprises a large football turf and an athletic running field. Hypermedia library
column9: petting zoo and art gallery can be found at Kompleks 3C MPSJ in SS13. There are many indoor soccer centres
column11: tennis and badminton courts in Subang Jaya. Golf clubs include the Subang Racquet and Golf Club
column12: Subang National Golf Club Glenmarie Golf & Country Club and Saujana Golf and Country Club.

column1: Subang Jaya is renowned as a light industrial hub in the Klang Valley. The main industrial areas in the city are Subang Industrial Park SS13
column2: Sime UEP Industrial Park
column3: Subang Hi-Tech Industrial Park and USJ 1 through USJ 8
column4: involving in both light and heavy industry.

column1: The Malaysia headquarters of PROTON Holdings
column2: the Centre of Excellence; Lotus Cars
column3: Faber-Castell and many other major international companies are located in Sime UEP Industrial Park.

column1: Subang Jaya is well known as a higher-education hub
column2: comprising many large international private colleges and universities. It also consists of over 30 primary and secondary schools including local
column3: private and international.

column1: Healthcare in Subang Jaya is provided by two private hospitals. They are Sime Darby Medical Centre Subang Jaya
column2: (formerly known as Subang Jaya Medical Centre (SJMC)) in SS12 along with Sunway Medical Centre in Bandar Sunway.

Subang Jaya has its first public health clinic called the 1 Malaysia Healthcare located in Taman Subang Mewah area of USJ 1. Its primary objective is to provide cheaper healthcare for lower to middle-income population.

column1: Darul Ehsan Mosque in SS15 is the main worshipping place of Muslims in Subang Jaya. There are other alternative mosques in the city in USJ 1
column2: USJ 9 and USJ 17.

column1: The Church of St Thomas More
column2: Subang Jaya (STM)
column3: is a Roman Catholic parish
column5: USJ. The Church was officially dedicated and opened on Sunday
column8: Archbishop of Kuala Lumpur. The other main church of Subang Jaya is First Baptist Church in SS17. Kingdom Life Church International
column10: is located in Jalan USJ Sentral 2
column11: USJ 1 The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints: With a strong congregation in Subang Jaya.

column1: Subang Jaya Buddhist Association (SJBA) commenced its activities in August 1989 and SJBA eventually became a community and spiritual center for many Buddhists in and around Subang Jaya. One of the memorable achievements of the Association is the successful building of the present Vihara (Temple) in 1997 on a ½ acre land obtained from the Selangor Government. The Vihara has been well utilized over these years.The Hindu Temple Sri Varatharajah Perumal Temple
column2: Gurdwara Sahib Subang and Subang Jaya Buddhist Association are located in SS13
column3: near the intersection between Kesas Highway and Persiaran Kewajipan.

column2: there are three large mixed commercial projects under development in Subang Jaya which are SJCC Subang
column3: SJ7 Trans-City and Tropicana Metropark. SJCC Subang and SJ7 Trans-City are two large mixed developments by Sime Darby that are set to be integrated with highly advanced public transportation. Da Men and Empire Remix are located in USJ 1. Da Men is a mixed commercial development sprawling over 8.6 acres of prime land comprising two blocks of serviced apartments
column4: retail lots and a 6-storey shopping podium. On the other hand
column5: Empire Remix is also a mixed commercial development which consists of a few blocks of office buildings
column6: serviced apartments and a shopping mall.

column1: Tropicana Metropark is an 88.5-acre development comprising more than 10 high-rise buildings which include office suites
column2: SOHO
column3: office towers
column6: shopfronts and a shopping mall. It is situated near the upscale neighbourhoods of USJ Heights and Subang Heights
column7: and is strategically located off the Federal Highway. A new access from Federal Highway will be completed by 2016 to improve the traffic flow around the area. On top of that
column8: Bandar Raya Developments Bhd (BRDB) is developing an RM2 billion 24 acres of integrated mixed development around the same area.

column1: Subang Jaya is well-connected to the cities of Kuala Lumpur
column2: Shah Alam and the townships of Petaling Jaya such as Ara Damansara
column3: Kota Damansara
column5: Damansara Utama and Mutiara Damansara via a network of major highways
column10: North South Expressway and LDP. There are three exits connecting Federal Highway to Subang Jaya. The two main exits are at exit 17.9 km through Persiaran Kewajipan and exit 18.2 km through Persiaran Tujuan
column11: while the alternative exit is through Persiaran Teknologi Subang at Tropicana Metropark's direct interchange.

column1: Persiaran Kewajipan and Persiaran Tujuan serve as the two major roads in Subang Jaya. The alternative route from USJ and Subang Jaya to Kuala Lumpur and Petaling Jaya is the Subang–Kelana Jaya Link
column2: which also connects the Persiaran Kewajipan roundabout of the New Pantai Expressway  towards the Subang Airport expressway (route 15) of Federal Highway .

column1: Subang Jaya's public transport system is highly developed
column2: boasting 2 light rail transit (LRT) lines
column3: 1 KTM commuter line
column5: bus and taxi services. Since 30 June 2016
column6: many new LRT stations of the extended Kelana Jaya Line have opened
column7: connecting various areas in Subang Jaya with Kuala Lumpur city centre and Petaling Jaya. The LRT stations are strategically located within walking distance from shopping malls
column8: commercial centres and residential areas and supported by feeder buses. The Kelana Jaya Line had been extended from the existing route from the Subang LRT Depot
column9: running through the Dana 1 commercial centre in Kelana Jaya
column11: then to Subang Parade (interchange with KTM Subang Jaya commuter station) which covers three stations within the town centre. Within USJ
column12: the LRT line continues from SS18 to USJ 7 (Da Men and Summit)
column16: and ends at the main interchange station hub in Putra Heights
column17: which connects with another LRT line
column18: the Sri Petaling Line to Puchong

column2: public bus transportation is provided by two companies
column3: RapidKL and Metrobus. These buses provide access around the town and also to Kuala Lumpur. Alternatively
column4: there is a BRT line connecting the Setia Jaya Komuter station through Bandar Sunway to the USJ7 LRT Station. The BRT Sunway Line started operating on June 1
column6: when it was officially launched by Malaysia prime minister
column7: Najib Razak. The BRT service is a public-private partnership project between Prasarana and Sunway Group which aims to provide eco-friendly electric bus services on elevated tracks for residents in Bandar Sunway and USJ.

column2: Subang Jaya is served by an urban-suburb rail link
column3: the KTM Komuter
column4: which provides transportation towards Port Klang and Kuala Lumpur.

column1: The Sultan Abdul Aziz Shah Airport is located at Subang
column2: Shah Alam. It serves as the main hub for turboprop airlines Firefly (a low-cost carrier subsidiary of Malaysia Airlines)
column3: Malindo Air and Berjaya Air and is the premier hub for corporate and private aviation in Southeast Asia.
